content: "http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/mar/02/no-headline---200903021148-04tjustis/" Now this is a great move. This is what ALL governments at all levels need to be looking at. Cutting the over paid beurocrats checks. I hope the rest of the states follow. It does not have to stop at the 100k and over level either. Each and every job needs to be looked at. Good going Florida! Great example to set!

title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...

content: Remember that state employees are not all office bureaucrats. State employees include the deans of state universities down to the research scientists who have worked there for decades. It includes teachers, principals, and even the school lunch ladies. It includes the metal shop worker down in the facilities area who has been working for years and has finally become the Facilities Supervisor. So remember when you say that "each and every job" needs to be looked at... how much more do you want to shave off of the salaries of those of us state employees who work hard and make only a moderate salary? What do you say to the dean of the college who has worked there for years and has worked his or her way up to the top? "You were successful so here's a pay cut"? Yes, we have to trim back, but be careful what you say when you think of "state employees" and you envision some fat-cat bureaucrats sitting in posh corner offices with their feet up on desks, eating catered lunches and taking luxury vacations. "State employee" covers a vast range of types of jobs.

Yes, we have to trim back, but be careful what you say when you think of "state employees" and you envision some fat-cat bureaucrats sitting in posh corner offices with their feet up on desks, eating catered lunches and taking luxury vacations. "State employee" covers a vast range of types of jobs.

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: "http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/mar/02/no-headline---200903021148-04tjustis/" Now this is a great move. This is what ALL governments at all levels need to be looking at. Cutting the over paid beurocrats checks. I hope the rest of the states follow. It does not have to stop at the 100k and over level either. Each and every job needs to be looked at. Good going Florida! Great example to set! The situation in Florida will have absolutely no impact on you, so before you go off leading the cheers, think about this. The article you cite mentions only the legal community specifically. It mentions that that the Judges that are over paid (and I agree) will then migrate to ambulance chaser's where they can earn more money. Then what happens? While I agree the legal system is screwed up, it's not just at the judge level--it's through out. However, you fail to mention further that the budget shortfall down here will have a greater impact and it's in teacher salary's and quite possibly jobs being cut or vacancies not being filled. Looking down the road, if education fails due to the lack of qualified teacher's, the next generation of voters will be educated how? We'll have another generation of voters that will align to another mesiah like they did last November? Good going Florida? What a great example to set? Would you like that to happen in Virginia too?

content: In South Florida, $100,000 is lower middle class. I make well over $100,000 per year in my civilian job (when I'm actually home), and I barely get by in Miami.
reply: In South Florida, $100,000 is lower middle class. I make well over $100,000 per year in my civilian job (when I'm actually home), and I barely get by in Miami.
title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...

content: quote: Originally posted by busnrete8: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: "http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/mar/02/no-headline---200903021148-04tjustis/" Now this is a great move. The situation in Florida will have absolutely no impact on you, so before you go off leading the cheers, think about this. The article you cite mentions only the legal community specifically. It mentions that that the Judges that are over paid (and I agree) will then migrate to ambulance chaser's where they can earn more money. Then what happens? While I agree the legal system is screwed up, it's not just at the judge level--it's through out. However, you fail to mention further that the budget shortfall down here will have a greater impact and it's in teacher salary's and quite possibly jobs being cut or vacancies not being filled. Looking down the road, if education fails due to the lack of qualified teacher's, the next generation of voters will be educated how? We'll have another generation of voters that will align to another mesiah like they did last November? Good going Florida? What a great example to set? Would you like that to happen in Virginia too? Without regard to the merits of a 5% pay cut for state employees earning over $100,000, I would simply point out that teacher salaries in Florida are established by individual schools and school districts so I question whether the cut would apply to them at all. If it does, in a lousy job market, it is unlikely that very many employees would quit, teachers or otherwise. Regardless, with the average teacher salary in Florida well below $50,000 (specifically $46,922 for the 07-08 school year), I doubt there would be a substantive impact in that arena anyway.

content: quote: Originally posted by mrmixitup: In South Florida, $100,000 is lower middle class. I make well over $100,000 per year in my civilian job (when I'm actually home), and I barely get by in Miami. No offense, but I find it hard to believe that a $100K salary is "lower-middle class" ANYWHERE in the United States. That seems like Comfortable-Middle to me. I lived in Boston, the second-most-expensive city in the country, on $40K/year, and I was middle-class because I knew how to budget. Miami is less expensive than Boston, for sure, so how do you figure that $100K is lower-middle class? It takes a pretty luxurious lifestyle to "barely get by" on $100K per year. Pardon me... "well over $100,000 per year."
quote: Originally posted by mrmixitup: In South Florida, $100,000 is lower middle class. I make well over $100,000 per year in my civilian job (when I'm actually home), and I barely get by in Miami.

I lived in Boston, the second-most-expensive city in the country, on $40K/year, and I was middle-class because I knew how to budget. Miami is less expensive than Boston, for sure, so how do you figure that $100K is lower-middle class? It takes a pretty luxurious lifestyle to "barely get by" on $100K per year. Pardon me... "well over $100,000 per year."

content: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Yes, we have to trim back, but be careful what you say when you think of "state employees" and you envision some fat-cat bureaucrats sitting in posh corner offices with their feet up on desks, eating catered lunches and taking luxury vacations. "State employee" covers a vast range of types of jobs. +1 There are a LOT of state employees that make beans...a big part of state bennies used to be a great retirement...up to 90% of pay or so. Of course, that has largely gone away, but pay rates never went up. It's easy to rail about "fat cat gubbmint employees", except most of them are making more like 30k/yr, not 100.

quote: Originally posted by busnrete8: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: Originally posted by busnrete8: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: "http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/mar/02/no-headline---200903021148-04tjustis/" Now this is a great move. It does not have to stop at the 100k and over level either. Each and every job needs to be looked at. Good going Florida! Great example to set! The situation in Florida will have absolutely no impact on you, so before you go off leading the cheers, think about this. The article you cite mentions only the legal community specifically. It mentions that that the Judges that are over paid (and I agree) will then migrate to ambulance chaser's where they can earn more money. Then what happens? While I agree the legal system is screwed up, it's not just at the judge level--it's through out. However, you fail to mention further that the budget shortfall down here will have a greater impact and it's in teacher salary's and quite possibly jobs being cut or vacancies not being filled. Looking down the road, if education fails due to the lack of qualified teacher's, the next generation of voters will be educated how? We'll have another generation of voters that will align to another mesiah like they did last November? Good going Florida? What a great example to set? Would you like that to happen in Virginia too? Without regard to the merits of a 5% pay cut for state employees earning over $100,000, I would simply point out that teacher salaries in Florida are established by individual schools and school districts so I question whether the cut would apply to them at all. If it does, in a lousy job market, it is unlikely that very many employees would quit, teachers or otherwise. Regardless, with the average teacher salary in Florida well below $50,000 (specifically $46,922 for the 07-08 school year), I doubt there would be a substantive impact in that arena anyway. I never said teachers would quit. I aid they would be cut or vacancies not filled.
reply: Fair enough. I interpreted it to be an argument against the 5% cut ... my bad.
title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...

content: "http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/mar/02/no-headline---200903021148-04tjustis/" Now this is a great move. This is what ALL governments at all levels need to be looking at. Cutting the over paid beurocrats checks. I hope the rest of the states follow. It does not have to stop at the 100k and over level either. Each and every job needs to be looked at. Good going Florida! Great example to set!

Good going Florida! Great example to set!
title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...

content: Remember that state employees are not all office bureaucrats. State employees include the deans of state universities down to the research scientists who have worked there for decades. It includes teachers, principals, and even the school lunch ladies. It includes the metal shop worker down in the facilities area who has been working for years and has finally become the Facilities Supervisor. So remember when you say that "each and every job" needs to be looked at... how much more do you want to shave off of the salaries of those of us state employees who work hard and make only a moderate salary? What do you say to the dean of the college who has worked there for years and has worked his or her way up to the top? "You were successful so here's a pay cut"? Yes, we have to trim back, but be careful what you say when you think of "state employees" and you envision some fat-cat bureaucrats sitting in posh corner offices with their feet up on desks, eating catered lunches and taking luxury vacations. "State employee" covers a vast range of types of jobs.
reply: Remember that state employees are not all office bureaucrats. State employees include the deans of state universities down to the research scientists who have worked there for decades. It includes teachers, principals, and even the school lunch ladies. It includes the metal shop worker down in the facilities area who has been working for years and has finally become the Facilities Supervisor. So remember when you say that "each and every job" needs to be looked at... how much more do you want to shave off of the salaries of those of us state employees who work hard and make only a moderate salary? What do you say to the dean of the college who has worked there for years and has worked his or her way up to the top? "You were successful so here's a pay cut"? Yes, we have to trim back, but be careful what you say when you think of "state employees" and you envision some fat-cat bureaucrats sitting in posh corner offices with their feet up on desks, eating catered lunches and taking luxury vacations. "State employee" covers a vast range of types of jobs.

content: quote: Originally posted by mrmixitup: In South Florida, $100,000 is lower middle class. I make well over $100,000 per year in my civilian job (when I'm actually home), and I barely get by in Miami. No offense, but I find it hard to believe that a $100K salary is "lower-middle class" ANYWHERE in the United States. That seems like Comfortable-Middle to me. I lived in Boston, the second-most-expensive city in the country, on $40K/year, and I was middle-class because I knew how to budget. Miami is less expensive than Boston, for sure, so how do you figure that $100K is lower-middle class? It takes a pretty luxurious lifestyle to "barely get by" on $100K per year. Pardon me... "well over $100,000 per year."
quote: Originally posted by mrmixitup: In South Florida, $100,000 is lower middle class. I make well over $100,000 per year in my civilian job (when I'm actually home), and I barely get by in Miami.
reply: No offense, but I find it hard to believe that a $100K salary is "lower-middle class" ANYWHERE in the United States. That seems like Comfortable-Middle to me. I lived in Boston, the second-most-expensive city in the country, on $40K/year, and I was middle-class because I knew how to budget. Miami is less expensive than Boston, for sure, so how do you figure that $100K is lower-middle class? It takes a pretty luxurious lifestyle to "barely get by" on $100K per year. Pardon me... "well over $100,000 per year."
title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...

content: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Yes, we have to trim back, but be careful what you say when you think of "state employees" and you envision some fat-cat bureaucrats sitting in posh corner offices with their feet up on desks, eating catered lunches and taking luxury vacations. "State employee" covers a vast range of types of jobs. +1 There are a LOT of state employees that make beans...a big part of state bennies used to be a great retirement...up to 90% of pay or so. Of course, that has largely gone away, but pay rates never went up. It's easy to rail about "fat cat gubbmint employees", except most of them are making more like 30k/yr, not 100.
quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Yes, we have to trim back, but be careful what you say when you think of "state employees" and you envision some fat-cat bureaucrats sitting in posh corner offices with their feet up on desks, eating catered lunches and taking luxury vacations. Of course, that has largely gone away, but pay rates never went up. It's easy to rail about "fat cat gubbmint employees", except most of them are making more like 30k/yr, not 100.
title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...

content: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: quote: Originally posted by mrmixitup: In South Florida, $100,000 is lower middle class. I make well over $100,000 per year in my civilian job (when I'm actually home), and I barely get by in Miami. No offense, but I find it hard to believe that a $100K salary is "lower-middle class" ANYWHERE in the United States. That seems like Comfortable-Middle to me. I lived in Boston, the second-most-expensive city in the country, on $40K/year, and I was middle-class because I knew how to budget. Miami is less expensive than Boston, for sure, so how do you figure that $100K is lower-middle class? It takes a pretty luxurious lifestyle to "barely get by" on $100K per year. Pardon me... "well over $100,000 per year." I'm obviously exaggerating a little, but in all seriousness Miami is just stupidly expensive to live and work. There's a reason housing there is taking a serious dump; a three bedroom median home was going for $500,000 in 2007. Other places similiar are: Palm Beach Tampa Fort Lauderdale The cities in the North and Central are cheap, though: Jacksonville Tallahassee Gainsville Orlando

title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...

content: quote: Originally posted by busnrete8: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: Originally posted by busnrete8: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: "http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/mar/02/no-headline---200903021148-04tjustis/" Now this is a great move. This is what ALL governments at all levels need to be looking at. Cutting the over paid beurocrats checks. I hope the rest of the states follow. It does not have to stop at the 100k and over level either. Each and every job needs to be looked at. Good going Florida! Great example to set! The situation in Florida will have absolutely no impact on you, so before you go off leading the cheers, think about this. The article you cite mentions only the legal community specifically. It mentions that that the Judges that are over paid (and I agree) will then migrate to ambulance chaser's where they can earn more money. Then what happens? While I agree the legal system is screwed up, it's not just at the judge level--it's through out. However, you fail to mention further that the budget shortfall down here will have a greater impact and it's in teacher salary's and quite possibly jobs being cut or vacancies not being filled. Looking down the road, if education fails due to the lack of qualified teacher's, the next generation of voters will be educated how? We'll have another generation of voters that will align to another mesiah like they did last November? Good going Florida? What a great example to set? Would you like that to happen in Virginia too? Without regard to the merits of a 5% pay cut for state employees earning over $100,000, I would simply point out that teacher salaries in Florida are established by individual schools and school districts so I question whether the cut would apply to them at all. If it does, in a lousy job market, it is unlikely that very many employees would quit, teachers or otherwise. Regardless, with the average teacher salary in Florida well below $50,000 (specifically $46,922 for the 07-08 school year), I doubt there would be a substantive impact in that arena anyway. I never said teachers would quit. I aid they would be cut or vacancies not filled. Fair enough. I interpreted it to be an argument against the 5% cut ... my bad.

Without regard to the merits of a 5% pay cut for state employees earning over $100,000, I would simply point out that teacher salaries in Florida are established by individual schools and school districts so I question whether the cut would apply to them at all. If it does, in a lousy job market, it is unlikely that very many employees would quit, teachers or otherwise. Regardless, with the average teacher salary in Florida well below $50,000 (specifically $46,922 for the 07-08 school year), I doubt there would be a substantive impact in that arena anyway. reply: Fair enough. I interpreted it to be an argument against the 5% cut ... my bad.
title: Florida seeks 5% pay cut for state employees making over $100k...
